(since 1975) | alma_mater = [[University of Hamburg]] | spouse = {{plainlist| * {{marriage|[[Britta Ernst]]|1998}} }} | website = {{Official URL}} | signature = Olaf Scholz Signature.svg }} '''Olaf Scholz''' ({{IPA|de|ˈoːlaf ˈʃɔlts|lang|De-Olaf Scholz.ogg}}; born {{Birth date|1958|06|14|df=yes}}) is a German politician who has been [[Chancellor of Germany]] since 2021. A member of the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|Social Democratic Party]] (SPD), he previously served as [[Vice-Chancellor of Germany|vice chancellor]] in the [[fourth Merkel cabinet]] and as [[Federal Ministry of Finance (Germany)|Federal Minister of Finance]] from 2018 to 2021. He was also [[List of mayors of Hamburg|First Mayor of Hamburg]] from 2011 to 2018, deputy leader of the SPD from 2009 to 2019, and [[Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs|Federal Minister of Labour and Social Affairs]] from 2007 to 2009. Scholz began his career as a lawyer specialising in [[employment law|labour and employment law]]. He became a member of the SPD in the 1970s and was a member of the [[Bundestag]] from 1998 to 2011. Scholz served in the [[Government of Hamburg|Hamburg Government]] under [[List of mayors of Hamburg|First Mayor]] [[Ortwin Runde]] in 2001 and became [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|general secretary]] of the SPD in 2002, where he served alongside SPD leader and then-chancellor [[Gerhard Schröder]]. He became his party's [[Chief Whip|chief whip]] in the Bundestag, later entering the [[First Merkel cabinet|First Merkel Government]] in 2007 as [[Federal Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs|Federal Minister for Labour and Social Affairs]]. After the SPD moved into the opposition following the [[2009 German federal election|2009 election]], Scholz returned to lead the SPD in Hamburg. He was then elected deputy leader of the SPD. He led his party to victory in the [[2011 Hamburg state election]] and became first mayor, a position he held until 2018. After the Social Democratic Party entered the [[Fourth Merkel cabinet|fourth Merkel government]] in 2018, Scholz was appointed as both minister of finance and Vice Chancellor of Germany. In 2020, he was nominated as the SPD's [[candidate]] for Chancellor of Germany for the [[2021 German federal election|2021 federal election]]. The party won a plurality of seats in the [[Bundestag]] and formed a "[[traffic light coalition]]" with [[Alliance 90/The Greens]] and the [[Free Democratic Party (Germany)|Free Democratic Party]]. On 8 December 2021, Scholz was elected and sworn in as chancellor by the Bundestag, succeeding [[Angela Merkel]]. As chancellor, Scholz has overseen Germany's response to the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]]. Despite giving a restrained and timid response compared to many other Western leaders, Scholz oversaw a significant increase in the German defence budget, [[List of military aid to Ukraine during the Russo-Ukrainian War|weapons shipments to Ukraine]], and the [[Nord Stream 2]] pipeline was put on hold. Three days after the invasion, Scholz set out the principles of a new German defence policy in his [[Zeitenwende speech]]. In September 2022, three of the four [[2022 Nord Stream pipeline sabotage|Nord Stream pipelines were destroyed]]. During the [[Israel–Hamas war]], he authorized substantial German [[Military aid|military]] and medical aid to Israel, and denounced the actions of [[Hamas]] and other [[Palestinian political violence|Palestinian militant groups]]. In November 2023, the [[Federal Constitutional Court]] demanded budget cuts totaling {{Euro|60{{nbsp}}billion}} to ensure the government would not surpass [[Debt limit|debt limits]] as set in the constitution;{{cite news|last=Martinez|first=Maria|date=15 November 2023|title=German court deals 60 billion euro budget blow to Scholz government|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/german-court-make-key-ruling-budget-manoeuvre-2023-11-15/|access-date=6 August 2024|url-status=live|archive-date=5 December 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231205192834/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/german-court-make-key-ruling-budget-manoeuvre-2023-11-15/}} this proved a significant challenge for Scholz's cabinet and contributed to the [[2023–2024 German farmers' protests|2023–2024 protests]].{{cite news|last=Moulson|first=Geir|date=2 February 2024|title=German lawmakers approve contested cuts to farmers' fuel subsidies and a revamped 2024 budget|work=Associated Press|url=https://apnews.com/article/germany-2024-budget-farmers-subsidies-protests-8e2e82a9ce37363df4473c22ed49ad6d|access-date=6 August 2024|url-status=live|archive-date=6 August 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240806025715/https://apnews.com/article/germany-2024-budget-farmers-subsidies-protests-8e2e82a9ce37363df4473c22ed49ad6d}} On 6 November 2024, [[2024 German government crisis|his government majority collapsed]] as he dismissed [[Christian Lindner]] from the post of [[Federal Ministry of Finance (Germany)|Federal Minister of Finance]] and broke up the coalition agreement. On 16 December 2024, Scholz lost a [[Motion of no confidence|vote of no confidence]]. On the same day, he requested the [[President of Germany]] to dissolve the Bundestag; the President, [[Frank-Walter Steinmeier]], did so and called out [[2025 German federal election|new elections]] for 23 February 2025. ==Early life and education== Scholz was born on 14 June 1958, in [[Osnabrück]], [[Lower Saxony]], and grew up in [[Hamburg]]'s [[Rahlstedt]] district.{{cite news|last=Cliffe|first=Jeremy|date=3 September 2021|title=How Olaf Scholz and the SPD could lead Germany's next government|work=[[New Statesman]]|url=https://www.newstatesman.com/german-election-2021/2021/09/how-olaf-scholz-and-the-spd-could-lead-germanys-next-government|access-date=27 September 2021|archive-date=24 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210924175225/https://www.newstatesman.com/german-election-2021/2021/09/how-olaf-scholz-and-the-spd-could-lead-germanys-next-government|url-status=live}} His parents worked in the [[textile industry]].{{cite news|last=Bennhold|first=Katrin|date=24 November 2021|title=He Convinced Voters He Would Be Like Merkel. But Who Is Olaf Scholz?|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/24/world/europe/germany-new-chancellor-olaf-scholz.html|access-date=25 November 2021|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=25 November 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211125194911/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/11/24/world/europe/germany-new-chancellor-olaf-scholz.html|url-status=live}} He has two younger brothers, Jens Scholz, an [[anesthesiologist]] and CEO of the [[University Medical Center Schleswig Holstein]];{{cite web |last1=Gammelin |first1=Cerstin |title=Olaf Scholz Bruder: Warum Jens Scholz in Paris berühmt |url=https://www.sueddeutsche.de/wirtschaft/olaf-scholz-bruder-jens-scholz-paris-1.4946439 |website=Süddeutsche Zeitung |access-date=7 September 2021 |language=de |date=25 June 2020 |archive-date=7 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210907150854/https://www.sueddeutsche.de/wirtschaft/olaf-scholz-bruder-jens-scholz-paris-1.4946439 |url-status=live }} and Ingo Scholz, a tech entrepreneur. Olaf Scholz attended the Bekassinenau elementary school in Oldenfelde, and then switched to the Großlohering elementary school in Großlohe. After graduating from high school in 1977, he began studying law at the [[University of Hamburg]] in 1978 as part of a one-stage legal training course.{{cite web |last=Schindler |first=Fabian |title=Stades Bürgermeister verkündet seinen Abschied |url=https://www.abendblatt.de/region/stade/article107978528/Stades-Buergermeister-verkuendet-seinen-Abschied.html |website=Hamburger Abendblatt |access-date=7 September 2021 |language=de |date=21 March 2011 |archive-date=7 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210807164046/https://www.abendblatt.de/region/stade/article107978528/Stades-Buergermeister-verkuendet-seinen-Abschied.html |url-status=live }} He later found employment as a lawyer specialising in labour and employment law, working at the law firm Zimmermann, Scholz und Partner.{{cite news |last1=Chazan |first1=Guy |title=Olaf Scholz, a sound guardian for Germany's finances |url=https://www.ft.com/content/170b9d0a-0cc2-11e8-8eb7-42f857ea9f09 |website=Financial Times |access-date=7 September 2021 |date=9 February 2018 |archive-date=26 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210826204338/https://www.ft.com/content/170b9d0a-0cc2-11e8-8eb7-42f857ea9f09 |url-status=live }} Scholz joined the [[Social Democratic Party of Germany|Social Democratic Party]] at the age of 17. Scholz's family is traditionally [[Lutheran]], and he was [[Baptism|baptized]] in the [[Protestant Church in Germany]]. He holds largely [[Secularity|secular]] political views, and left the Church in adulthood, but has emphasised a need for appreciation of Germany's Christian heritage and culture.{{cite news |title=Scholz: Christliche Prägung unserer Kultur wertschätzen |url=https://www.katholisch.de/artikel/31307-scholz-christliche-praegung-unserer-kultur-wertschaetzen |access-date=26 September 2021 |archive-date=20 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210920152940/https://www.katholisch.de/artikel/31307-scholz-christliche-praegung-unserer-kultur-wertschaetzen |url-status=live }} ==Political career== {{Social democracy sidebar|people}} ===Early political career=== ====Young socialist, 1975–1989==== [[File:Olaf Scholz 1984.jpg|thumb|left|Scholz at the [[Young Socialists in the SPD|Young Socialists Congress]], 1984]] Scholz joined the [[SPD]] in 1975 as a student, where he came into contact with the [[Young Socialists in the SPD|Jusos]], the youth organization of the SPD. From 1982 to 1988, he was Deputy Federal Chairman of the Jusos. Scholz was also Vice President of the [[International Union of Socialist Youth]] from 1987 to 1989. He supported the Freudenberger Kreis, a [[Marxist]] wing of the Jusos' university groups, arguing that society should "overcome the capitalist economy" in one of his publications.{{cite web|first1=Markus|last1=Feldenkirchen|first2=Michael|last2=Sauga|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-54076837.html|title=Rückkehr eines Bauernopfers|website=Der Spiegel|date=26 November 2007|access-date=2 October 2024|archive-date=23 March 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323210604/http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-54076837.html|url-status=live}} In it, Scholz criticized the "aggressive-imperialist [[NATO]]", the [[Germany|Federal Republic]] as the "European stronghold of big business" and the [[social-liberal coalition]], which puts the "bare maintenance of power above any form of substantive dispute".{{cite web|title=Kann er Kanzler?: Olaf Scholz – ein kritisches Porträt über den Kanzlerkandidaten der SPD|periodical=[[Handelsblatt]]|publisher=|url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/politik/deutschland/kann-er-kanzler-olaf-scholz-ein-kritisches-portraet-ueber-den-kanzlerkandidaten-der-spd/26106816.html|access-date=|first1=Martin|last1=Greive|first2=Jan|last2=Hildebrand|first3=Christian|last3=Rickens|first4=Klaus|last4=Stratmann|date=21 August 2020|language=de|pages=|quote=}} Referring to this period in his life, Scholz later said that he "made almost all possible mistakes at some point". October 2021|date=24 September 2021|language=|pages=|quote=}} ====Member of the Bundestag, 1998–2001==== Scholz was elected to his first political office as a Deputy Member of the Bundestag representing the constituency of [[Hamburg-Altona (electoral district)|Hamburg-Altona]] in [[1998 German federal election|1998]], aged 40.{{cite web|date=18 April 2013|title=Olaf Scholz, MdB|url=https://www.spdfraktion.de/abgeordnete/scholz|access-date=8 December 2021|website=SPD-Bundestagsfraktion|language=de|archive-date=8 December 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208135326/https://www.spdfraktion.de/abgeordnete/scholz|url-status=live}} During his tenure, Scholz served on the [https://www.bundestag.de/en/committees/a11 Committee for Labor and Social Matters]. In the committee of inquiry into the visa affair of the Bundestag, he was chairman of the SPD parliamentary group.{{cite web|title=DeutschlandRadio Berlin – Interview – Scholz: Politisch Verantwortliche erst später vernehmen|url=https://www.deutschlandradio.de/archiv/dlr/sendungen/interview_dlr/348552/index.html|access-date=8 December 2021|website=www.deutschlandradio.de|archive-date=8 December 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208135318/https://www.deutschlandradio.de/archiv/dlr/sendungen/interview_dlr/348552/index.html|url-status=dead}} Scholz resigned his mandate on 6 June 2001, to take office as Senator.{{Clarify|date=June 2023}} Because his seat was an [[overhang seat]], it was not filled until the [[2002 German federal election]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2023}} ====Senator for the Interior of Hamburg, 2001==== On 30 May 2001, Scholz succeeded Hartmuth Wrocklage to become [[Government of Hamburg|Senator for the Interior of Hamburg]] in the Senate led by Mayor [[Ortwin Runde]]. Wrocklage had resigned due to allegations of nepotism. He also succeeded Wrocklage as [[German Bundesrat#Today|Deputy Member]] of the [[German Bundesrat|Bundesrat]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2023}} During his brief time as Senator, Scholz controversially{{Clarify|date=June 2023}} approved the involuntary use of [[Vomiting|emetics]] to gather evidence from suspected drug dealers.{{cite web|date=23 September 2021|title=Olaf Scholz: The Teflon candidate|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/olaf-scholz-teflon-candidate-germany-election-2021/|access-date=16 December 2021|website=POLITICO|language=en-US|archive-date=2 October 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241002144449/https://www.politico.eu/article/olaf-scholz-teflon-candidate-germany-election-2021/|url-status=live}} The Hamburg Medical Chamber expressed disapproval of this practice due to potential health risks.{{cite web |title=Kein ärztlicher Eingriff mit Gewalt |trans-title=No forced medical intervention |date=30 October 2001 |url=http://www.aerztekammer-hamburg.de/funktionen/news/content_presse_archiv.php3?saveDate=1004396400 |language=de |website=Pressestelle der Ärztekammer Hamburg |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101119142831/http://www.aerztekammer-hamburg.de/funktionen/news/content_presse_archiv.php3?saveDate=1004396400 |archive-date=19 November 2010 |access-date=13 September 2021 }} Scholz left office in October 2001, after the defeat of his party at the [[2001 Hamburg state election]] and the election of [[Ole von Beust]] as First Mayor. His successor was [[Ronald Schill]], who had won on a [[Law and order (politics)|Law and order]] platform, with an emphasis on harsh penalties for drug dealers.{{cite web |last=Gärtner |first=Birgit |date=28 May 2021 |title=Olaf Scholz: einst Kapitalismuskritik, dann Sozialabbau |url=https://www.heise.de/tp/features/Olaf-Scholz-einst-Kapitalismuskritik-dann-Sozialabbau-6056131.html |access-date=8 December 2021 |website=Telepolis |language=de |archive-date=8 December 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208144004/https://www.heise.de/tp/features/Olaf-Scholz-einst-Kapitalismuskritik-dann-Sozialabbau-6056131.html |url-status=live }}{{cite web|title=Ronald Schill: Chronik einer kurzen Polit-Karriere|url=https://www.manager-magazin.de/unternehmen/karriere/a-261886.html|access-date=8 December 2021|website=Manager-Magazin|date=19 August 2003|language=de|archive-date=9 December 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211209195339/https://www.manager-magazin.de/unternehmen/karriere/a-261886.html|url-status=live}} === Federal and state political career === ====Member of the Bundestag, 2002–2011==== Scholz was elected again to the [[Bundestag]] in the [[2002 German federal election]]. From 2002 to 2004, Scholz also served as [[Secretary-General|General Secretary of the SPD]]; he resigned from that office when party leader and Chancellor [[Gerhard Schröder]], facing disaffection within his own party and hampered by persistently low public approval ratings, announced he would step down as Leader of the Social Democratic Party.{{Cite news |last=Bernstein |first=Richard |date=7 February 2004 |title=Schröder Quitting Party Post, Citing Need to Pursue Reforms |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/07/world/schroder-quitting-party-post-citing-need-to-pursue-reforms.html |access-date=23 June 2023 |issn=0362-4331 |archive-date=13 February 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213021639/http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/07/world/schroder-quitting-party-post-citing-need-to-pursue-reforms.html |url-status=live }} Scholz was one of a series of politicians who sparked debate over the German journalistic norm of allowing interviewees to "authorize" and amend quotes before publication. This came after his press team insisted on extensively editing an interview with ''[[Die Tageszeitung]]'' in 2003.Moritz Schuller (7 September 2003), [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2003/dec/08/mondaymediasection7 The right to revise] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008032029/https://www.theguardian.com/media/2003/dec/08/mondaymediasection7 |date=8 October 2016 }} ''[[The Guardian]]''Ben Knight (19 January 2016), [http://www.dw.com/en/time-to-end-interview-authorization-in-germany/a-18989875 Time to end interview authorization in Germany?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123045333/http://www.dw.com/en/time-to-end-interview-authorization-in-germany/a-18989875 |date=23 January 2016 }} ''[[Deutsche Welle]]'' ''Die Tageszeitung'' editor [[Bascha Mika]] condemned the norm as a "betrayal of the claim to a free press", and the newspaper ultimately published the interview with Scholz's answers blacked out.{{Cite news|date=28 November 2003|title=Geheime Verschlusssache Interview|language=de|pages=1|work=Die Tageszeitung: taz|url=https://taz.de/!673398/|access-date=8 December 2021|issn=0931-9085|archive-date=8 December 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208140152/https://taz.de/!673398/|url-status=live}}{{cite web|last=Wieduwilt|first=Hendrik|date=6 October 2021|title=Die Autorisierung von Interviews: ein Machtkampf|url=https://uebermedien.de/63772/die-autorisierung-von-interviews-ein-machtkampf/|access-date=8 December 2021|website=Übermedien|language=de-DE|archive-date=2 October 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241002144453/https://uebermedien.de/63772/die-autorisierung-von-interviews-ein-machtkampf/|url-status=live}} Scholz served as the SPD spokesperson on the inquiry committee investigating the 2005 [[German Visa Affair 2005|German Visa Affair]]. The stimulus package included support for businesses and freelancers as well as a decision to keep factories open.
